rules.name: Swift Indentation
rules.rule: Use tabs for indentation in Swift files

rules.name: Function Spacing
rules.rule: Leave a single blank line between functions

rules.name: Variable declarations
rules.rule: Group related property declarations together. Start with @Published properties, followed by dependencies, then private properties

rules.name: Naming Convention
rules.rule: Use camelCase for properties, functions, and variables. Use PascalCase for types, protocols and file names

rules.name: Commenting
rules.rule: Use Swift comment conventions: // for single-line comments and /* */ for multi-line comments. Each file should have a standard header comment

rules.name: MARK Usage
rules.rule: Use MARK: - Section Name to organize code sections in larger files

rules.name: Private Properties
rules.rule: Mark properties as private when they are only used within the class/struct

rules.name: Trailing Whitespace
rules.rule: Remove trailing whitespace from all lines

rules.name: Line Length
rules.rule: Keep line length under 100 characters when possible

rules.name: Braces Style
rules.rule: Opening braces should be on the same line as the declaration, closing braces should be on a new line

rules.name: Class/Struct Organization
rules.rule: Organize types in this order: properties, initializers, lifecycle methods, public methods, private methods

rules.name: View Model Organization
rules.rule: In view models, group API calls together and separate them from UI-related code

rules.name: SwiftUI View Organization
rules.rule: In SwiftUI views, organize in this order: properties, body, helper view methods, preview

rules.name: Force Unwrapping
rules.rule: Avoid force unwrapping (!) optionals when possible. Use guard let, if let, or nil coalescing

rules.name: Empty Lines
rules.rule: No consecutive empty lines (maximum one empty line)

rules.name: Early Returns
rules.rule: Use early returns to reduce nesting and complexity

rules.name: Self Usage
rules.rule: Use self explicitly only when required (in closures or to disambiguate)

rules.name: File Organization
rules.rule: Follow MVVM architecture with separate folders for Models, Views, ViewModels, and Services

rules.name: Asset Naming
rules.rule: Use snake_case for asset names

rules.name: Function Parameter Formatting
rules.rule: For functions with multiple parameters that span multiple lines, align the parameters

rules.name: Reusable Components
rules.rule: Create and use reusable components when UI patterns repeat across the application. Extract common UI elements into separate View files

rules.name: APIService Usage
rules.rule: Always use the APIService methods for network calls. Never implement direct URL session calls in ViewModels

rules.name: Singleton Pattern Usage
rules.rule: ALWAYS use AppCache.shared directly instead of creating @ObservedObject or @StateObject properties. Never use '@ObservedObject private var appCache = AppCache.shared' or similar patterns. Access AppCache.shared directly in code. For UserAuthViewModel, use UserAuthViewModel.shared directly as well.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Universal Colors
rules.rule: ALWAYS use app-defined colors from Constants.swift instead of SwiftUI's default colors. Use universalBackgroundColor instead of .white, universalAccentColor instead of .black or .primary, universalSecondaryColor instead of .accentColor. Never use Color.primary, Color.secondary, .white, .black directly.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Figma Colors
rules.rule: For UI elements that match the Figma design, ALWAYS use the figma-prefixed colors (figmaBlue, figmaSoftBlue, figmaBlack300, figmaBlack400, figmaGreen, figmaBittersweetOrange) instead of creating custom colors or using SwiftUI defaults.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Backgrounds
rules.rule: For backgrounds, use universalBackgroundColor for main backgrounds, authPageBackgroundColor for auth screens. Never use Color.white, .background, or system background colors directly.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Text Colors
rules.rule: For text colors, use universalAccentColor for primary text, figmaBlack300 for secondary text, universalPlaceHolderTextColor for placeholder text. Avoid .primary, .secondary, or .foregroundColor without specifying the exact color.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Interactive Elements
rules.rule: For buttons and interactive elements, use figmaBlue for primary actions, figmaSoftBlue for secondary actions, universalPassiveColor for disabled states. Never use system accent colors or .tint without explicit color definition.

rules.name: App Color Usage - Activity Colors
rules.rule: For activity-related UI, use the predefined activityColors array or activityColorHexCodes. Each activity should have consistent color usage across all screens.

rules.name: Color Constants Import
rules.rule: All color constants are defined in Views/Helpers/Constants.swift. Import this file or ensure colors are accessible when creating new views. Never hardcode hex values directly in views.

rules.name: Debug Statements
rules.rule: NEVER add debug statements (print, NSLog, debugPrint, etc.) unless explicitly instructed by the user. Debug statements clutter the console, impact performance, and should only be added when actively debugging a specific issue. Remove debug statements after debugging is complete. Focus on clean, readable code without debug output.

rules.name: popup_overlay_colors
rules.description: Guidelines for popup and overlay color consistency
rules.rule: For popups and overlays, ALWAYS use adaptive colors that work in both light and dark modes. For semi-transparent overlays, use Color.black.opacity(0.6) for dark backgrounds and Color.white.opacity(0.6) for light backgrounds. For popup backgrounds, use universalBackgroundColor with appropriate opacity. For text, use universalAccentColor. For destructive actions, use universalTertiaryColor (red). Never hardcode colors like Color(red: 0.13, green: 0.13, blue: 0.13) - these break in light mode. Use environment-aware colors or the Color(UIColor { traitCollection in ... }) pattern for complex adaptive colors.

rules.name: Build Check After Changes
rules.rule: After making code changes, ALWAYS run a build check to ensure the code compiles successfully. Use 'xcodebuild -scheme Spawn-App-iOS-SwiftUI build' or build in Xcode to verify changes don't introduce compilation errors. This helps catch syntax errors, missing imports, type mismatches, and other issues early in the development process.

rules.name: Singleton Pattern - Environment Objects
rules.rule: NEVER instantiate singleton classes when passing them as environment objects. ALWAYS access singletons via their .shared property. Use .environmentObject(UserAuthViewModel.shared) NOT .environmentObject(UserAuthViewModel()). This ensures consistent global state across the app. Common singletons: UserAuthViewModel.shared, NotificationService.shared, KeychainService.shared.

rules.name: Figma-to-Code Plugin Output
rules.rule: Use Figma-to-code output ONLY to understand visual design and layout intent. NEVER copy generated code directly into the project. ALWAYS translate designs using the project's existing styling system. Replace hardcoded colors with Constants.swift colors, use Onest font extensions (.onestSemiBold), use responsive sizing patterns, and avoid complex offset/frame calculations.

rules.name: Figma Translation Guidelines
rules.rule: When translating Figma designs: Replace Color(red: X, green: Y, blue: Z) with figma-prefixed colors (figmaBlue, figmaSoftBlue, etc.). Replace Font.custom('Onest', size: X) with .onestSemiBold(size: X). Replace exact .frame(width: X, height: Y) with responsive sizing. Replace complex .offset() chains with proper layout containers. Use consistent padding patterns instead of hardcoded spacing.

rules.name: DTO Property Validation
rules.rule: ALWAYS verify DTO structure and available properties before accessing them in code. NEVER assume properties exist on DTOs. Check DTO definitions in Models/DTOs/ first. CalendarActivityDTO has: id, date, icon, colorHexCode, activityId. FullFeedActivityDTO has: title, note (not description), startTime, endTime, location. Use activityId from CalendarActivityDTO to fetch FullFeedActivityDTO when complete info is needed.

rules.name: Navigation Back Button Rules
rules.rule: NEVER create custom back buttons in views presented via NavigationLink - they automatically get system back buttons, creating duplicates. Use .navigationTitle() and .navigationBarTitleDisplayMode() instead. Only use custom back buttons for modal presentations (sheet, fullScreenCover) or custom navigation implementations.

rules.name: SwiftUI Environment Objects Best Practices
rules.rule: Use @EnvironmentObject for shared state accessed by multiple views. Pass environment objects at the highest level possible in view hierarchy. ALWAYS use existing singleton instances rather than creating new ones. For shared state: @EnvironmentObject, for view-owned objects: @StateObject, for objects passed from parent: @ObservedObject.

rules.name: DTO Common Property Mappings
rules.rule: Know the correct DTO property names: CalendarActivityDTO (id, date, icon, colorHexCode, activityId), FullFeedActivityDTO (title, note, startTime, endTime, location), BaseUserDTO (id, username, name, profilePictureURL). Use 'note' not 'description'. Use 'name' not 'title' for user names. Handle optional properties with nil coalescing or optional binding.

rules: NEVER suggest 'sudo rm -rf' commands involving system directories or user library folders
NEVER suggest deleting entire DerivedData directories without explicit user confirmation
ALWAYS use specific file paths rather than wildcards when deleting
PREFER less destructive alternatives like 'xcodebuild clean' over manual deletion
AVOID suggesting sudo commands unless absolutely necessary
ALWAYS explain why sudo is needed and what the command does
PREFER user-level solutions over system-level changes

preferred_order: Suggest restarting Xcode or simulator second
Manual file deletion only as last resort with user confirmation

real_time_updates: ALWAYS ensure UI updates happen on MainActor
ALWAYS call objectWillChange.send() after data mutations
PREFER @ObservedObject over @StateObject for passed view models
component_organization: AVOID duplicate layout components across files
PREFER shared components in dedicated files
ENSURE proper state management for reactive UIs
